content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are willing to take risks and are fairly comfortable with uncertainty. You tend to embrace new opportunities even if they involve some risk. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Given my risk-taking nature and comfort with uncertainty, I would choose to play this game as an opportunity for potential high rewards. However, since it's impossible to know the other player's strategy, I would strive for a balanced approach that maximizes my expected value over the long run.

In this game, I could consider using a mixed strategy, where I randomly pick R or B in each round, with a slight bias towards R because of the higher payoff when both players pick R (45$ vs 20$). A simple way to implement this might be to choose R 51% of the time and B 49% of the time. This strategy assumes that my opponent will also play randomly, and over the long run, I can expect a positive expected value.

In conclusion, my choice would be {R}, but with a slight bias towards playing R more frequently than B throughout the game. However, it's essential to remember that this is just one approach among many possible strategies, and ultimately, the results will depend on the actual behavior of my opponent.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

Having played R previously, which resulted in a 0$ payout, I will now adjust my strategy slightly to minimize losses. In this scenario, it seems that my opponent tends to choose B when I pick R. To exploit this apparent pattern, I could try switching my choice to B for the next round, hoping that they might switch to R, increasing the chances of both us picking R in a future round and securing a higher payout.

However, since it's impossible to know with certainty whether my opponent will indeed switch their choice, I might also consider sticking with my previous strategy of choosing R 51% of the time and B 49% of the time, as this approach still provides a positive expected value over the long run.

In conclusion, I will choose {B} for the next round, with the intention of inducing my opponent to switch their choice, but without completely abandoning my previous strategy of playing R more frequently than B.

To capitalize on this apparent pattern, I will continue to choose R for the next round, hoping that my opponent will switch back to choosing R, which would result in both of us earning 45$ if we both pick R again.

In conclusion, I will choose {R} for the next round, with the intention of exploiting my opponent's potential tendency to switch their choice after having previously chosen R themselves.
